Posts.Content: Calligirl I wouldn't worry yet either. They are just taking a precaution. Whatever they saw, could be any number of things not related to cancer. They just want to get a closer look. I have heard of many women who have had to go in for "second looks" through the years, none of which showed cancer. It IS SCARY though ,to be called back, and only natural to worry. Best wishes and let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: First Mammogram Results (need some advice) 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Angela- It is rare but not unheard of that someone so young developes breast cancer. The odds are in your favor that it is somethingelse, as 80% of lumps are benign. Nevertheless, I would DEFINETELY get the mammogram. -You can never be too careful about these things. As I understand it today's mammograms give only a fraction of radiation, that the old mammos gave. It really is better to be safe than sorry and to know for sure what you are dealing with. Are they going to do an ultrasound too? Sometimes these catch things, not seen on mammogram. I am one yr out form stage 1 breast cancer. - Mine was caught on a routine mammogram. I am much older than you, 48 at diagnosis. Best of luck, and please go have it checked out. Leea
Posts.Title: Breast Lump Found...Might Need Mammogram, have Questions

Posts.Content: Phy- Someone said on another breast cancer web site I visit, "If the cancer is more aggressive, it just means they will treat it more agressively." - In other words, there are excellent treatments for ALL types of breast cancer and we just have to tailor the treatment to what is going on with that pt. - You just have to hit it a little harder with a more agressive cancer and it sounds like that is exactly what your doc's are doing. Best of luck, Leea
Posts.Title: her2 positive

Posts.Content: Blazegirl, The only way to know for sure is to get an exam, mammogram and probably an ultrasound. They may then want to biopsy it, depending on what they find from the other tests. I've read 80% of breast lumps and bumps are benign. Can you let your Dr's office know, that you are really worried and could they work you in? I was dxed with early stage breast cancer, through mammogram in 06. My situation is probably much different than yours, as I have a family hx of breast cancer. Good luck with your exam and let's hope it's nothing more than another cyst or some other beneign condition. Let us know how things turn out. Leea
Posts.Title: Tiny hard lump

Posts.Content: Sivad, If it were me, I would absolutely get the biopsy. If it is suspicious, it is better to be safe than sorry and the only way they can tell is a biopsy. As you say, there is a good chance it is nothing, but I would rather know than wait. I was dxed with breast cancer in 06, with a suspicous area on mammogram. Thankfully it was caught early at stage 1 and I am doing well aalmost 2yrs later. Good luck with your decision. Leea
Posts.Title: Suspicious Finding

Posts.Content: Marmar, I agree with you. There is no way they know for sure what the lump really is until it's biopsied. I would absolutely insist that they do one. We will hope it is beneign, but nevertheless, I wouldn't rely only on a mammogram and manual exam. Leea
Posts.Title: i am so confused!!Any ideas???

Posts.Content: I had a core needle biopsy on a Thursday and given results, the following Monday. Hoping for beneign results for you. Leea
Posts.Title: How long for results of breast biopsy?

Posts.Content: Marion- I was 48 at dx in 06 with stage 1, grade 2, ER+/PR+/Her2-. I too have a family hx. I did have genetic testing and was found negative for BRCA genes, but I DO believe there is probably a "faulty gene" as well, for those of us with a family hx, but NOT BRCA positive. - they just haven't discovered it yet. As the other poster said, invasive cancer is always serious d/t some risk of recurrance. A grade 3 can be a little more aggresive, so it is good your daughter is having chemo. It really is a crapshoot as to who recurs, but there are many, many women who will be fine after treatment. I am almost 3yrs out and doing well. Leea
Posts.Title: HOW SERIOUS IS sTAGE 1 GRADE BREAST CANCER NO LYMPH NODES INVOLVED

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline- My experience was a little different than yours. I do have a family hx of breast cancer as well. I had microcalcifications in the R breast in fall 05'. I also had a sterostatic biopsy. The lab report showed beniegn micro calc and I was to come back in 6 mths to moniter it. I did the repeat mamo in 4/06. This time something suspicious was found in the L breast. This time had a core biopsy. Unfortuntately turned out to be cancer but very early stage 1. R breast was fine. Anyway d/t family hx, I opted for bilateral mast and then was on tamox. I did have genetic testing and was found not to be BRCA positive (BRCA cancer is usually more aggressive). I was not working at the time, so don't know how it would affect work/insurance issues. Our insurance company did pay in full. (It is a very expensive test >$3,000.) Anyway, it is now 4 yrs later and I am doing well. - I was dxed at 48. Hope I answered some of your questions. Leea
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: I didn't really have any side effects from the tamox, except it did make my fibroid's grow. It did raise my HDL (good chol). - None of this was completely surprising to me since it is a psuedo-estrogen. The tamox is just a precaution, in case there are any stray cancer cells floating around in the blood. Good luck with your procedure. Leea
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: I have had flap reconstruction. I had a bilateral mast in May of 06. I waited to research my options and than had I-GAP in March of 07. With I-GAP they use fat from your lower-outer behind to create the breasts. They do this if they think you don't have enough tummy to reconstruct. It is a big surgery; 7hrs for me, with two surgeon's, one doing each breast, but I would do it again in a minute, as I am very happy with the results. To prepare for flap surgery, I would: -Make sure you are in the best possible shape, physically and emotionally. -Eat healthy and take at least a multivitamin, get enough rest and light exercise or activity to make sure your immune system is strong. -Envision your surgery going well. Decrease stress, if you can. -When you go to the hospital pack some loose or button-down tops. -I stayed in the hospital 4 days. -After surgery you will have a pain pump. I did not have alot of pain d/t the pump and oral pain meds. -You will probably be very weak and tired and possibly nauseous those 1st few days d/t the anesthesia and meds. Rest, rest rest! BUT, they will also encourage you to walk the halls to prevent blood clots. Also drink lot's of water and deep breathing or coughing is good to get the anesthesia out of your sytem and keep your lungs strong. - It took me about 2 weeks to feel semi-normal and about 4 wks to feel almost back to my old self. -One thing you will have are drains. The docs all have different criteria for when to remove drains. That was the worst part for me and mine stayed in the lower hip area almost 4 wks. BUT, if you do the tummy fat surgery (DIEP) I don't think the drains have to stay in as long. After surgery, just try to pace yourself and listen to your body. I was 49 when I had the surgery and in good shape but a big surgery like that still takes alot out of you. Good luck and let us know what you decide. Leea -
Posts.Title: mastectomy/reconstruction 1 2

Posts.Content: TJ- I had one too. It wasn't too bad. They will numb the area. The instrument they use sounds like a "pop" when they extract the tissue, but since you are numbed, you only feel a little pressure. When you go home, they will encourage you to use something like frozen peas off and on for about 24hrs to help with any swelling. The area will be a little bruised for about a week and then it should look fine. When I have procedures, I always close my eyes and try to relax. Not easy but I think you'll be OK. Will be thinking of you. Best wishes. Leea
Posts.Title: Core biopsy with ultrsound

Posts.Content: My situation was a little different, in that I had double mastectomy and then delayed reconstruction, 9mths later. The reason I delayed, is I was so overwhelmed with all the "reconstruction choices", that I wanted to wait. The masts were in 06 and then reconstruction in Spring of 07. Anyway, you are talking about mast with "immediate" reconstruction. Regarding bilateral mast, surprisingly recovery is about a week. I was amazed how good I felt, even in 24hrs. Had to rest alot and took a long nap each afternoon but otherwise was able to move around as usual. - Although they do warn you about reaching above your head and lifting, of course. By about day 5, I even went to see a movie with my sister. You will have drains and they will be taken out in about a week,as well. I did not get implants, but used my own tissue for the reconstruction. If you get implants, from what i've heard, the recovery is easier. So I would say you should be able to go back to work in 1 week. - But you could ask for 2 weeks if you want to get extra rest, make sure you are totally healed and the drains are out. Leea
Posts.Title: mastectomy & reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Marla- I don't think this board allows us to post web sites but if you go on the web and type in breast cancer, you will find a couple of big sites with many, many discussion boards. As far as tamox vs Femara, it is true if you are premenopausal, they only offer tamox. You are not supposed to take any of the arromatase inhibitors like femara, if you are premenopausal. - Anyway, I was premenopausal at 48 when dxed and now 50. I am certain I would still be premenopausal and feeling great without hot flashes or any other menopausal side effects, BUT, since I have a family hx, my onc felt it important that I take shots to "shut down" my hormones, like an artifical menopause. I did not have chemo because my recurrance risk was very low, but instead went the anti-hormone route, since as you know hormone positive breast cancer cells, feed on hormones. Anyway, hopefully, you can find the br ca site I go to. - but stay on this one as well, if you can. - I have learned alot on here as well and talked with many wonderful ladies. Leea
Posts.Title: Her 2 Positive Breast Cancer ... Help !!

Posts.Content: Hi Marla- I am a breast cancer survivor as well, 2yrs out. I go to another site where they list several things you can take. Many women find alot of relief with effexor, which is an antidepressant but also works to minimize hot flashes. Some women are rxed gabapentin ( nuerontin) which can be used "off label" for hot flashes. Others try evening primrose. I myself have had alot of trouble with hot flashes, but they have settled down some in the past 6 mths. I tried nuerontin for a few mths but it made me feel weird and dizzy, so I just use natural remedies. this is what helps me some and other survivor's as well: -Avoid or limit caffeine, as this will make it worse. -Avoid or limit wine, " " " " " " -Wear layers and only natural fibers, like cotton. -Keep room air low and rooms well ventilated, so as to not get overheated. I do really well at about 72-73 degrees, but the minute a family member turns the AC above 73, I can feel it immediately. -Keep ice water next to your chair or bedside. -Use fans. -Exercise. - You will notice less hot flashes on days you exercise. Best of luck. I have only 3 more yrs of my anti-hormone med, Femara, thank God. Leea -
Posts.Title: Her 2 Positive Breast Cancer ... Help !!

Posts.Content: Hi Laura- I am hormone receptor positive and am taking Femara (similar to Armidex). From what I know the docs gear our treatment based on hormone status and also whether we tested + or- for the her2 gene. I don't think hormone status of each person is necessarily good or bad, but just different.I've read that hormone negative ladies respond well to chemo. Hormone positive women may or maynot have chemo depending on several things re their tumor and they usually recommend, as you say, anti-hormone thereapy, as either tamox (premenopausal) or armidex, femara or aromasin ( aromatase inhibitors for post menopausal or those that cannot take tamox). I have 3 more yrs to go on Femara and then am finished. Leea
Posts.Title: 5 year pill therapy

Posts.Content: Ticks- So sorry about your aunt and now your mother. I have a family hx too. My mom was dxed when I was 23. She is now a 28yr survivor and is 84 yrs old. My aunt was dxed very late in life at age 80 and is now 90. I was dxed 2 yrs ago at age 48.- I have a very good prognosis and plan on living a long life, as well! We all had invasive infitrating or it is usually called, invasive ductal carcinoma.(IDC) One thing I would advise with a family hx such as yours, is to follow-up with a good breast cancer or breast health center where you and your sister can get specialized screening including ultrasounds and MRIs, so that if heaven forbid, you develop it, it WILL be caught early. - EVEN if you have to drive an hr or two to get to a good breast center, IT IS WORTH IT. As far as helping your mom, a friend of mine did alot of "checking in with me", via phone. She was always ready to listen to me vent about treatment or my fears ect. She also sent "care packages" now and then to keep my spirits up. Both these things ment alot to me. I did not have chemo, but know many that did. If your mom has chemo, other's have told me just helping with meals, keeping the fridge stocked and helping with cleaning and laundry is great. She may have "taste changes" with chemo and only certain foods may taste good.- Get her whatever food she likes. Best wishes to you and your family. Leea
Posts.Title: Mother and Aunt with cancer

Posts.Content: I would call the testing site and have the radiologist or his/her nurse, explain the results of the Dec. 18th mammogram and why they want to do further testing. Leea
Posts.Title: 3rd mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi Ink, I have had the core needle biopsy. They will numb the area. When they get the tissue, it does sound like a "pop". - It went very fast and I did not feel any pain, only a little pulling. When it's over, they will have you apply some pressure. They gave me a small bag of tightly wrapped ice, to place on the area. - they want you to keep the area "iced", off and on for 24hrs. You can use some frozen peas wrapped in a baggy. It was certainly no fun, but not a terrible experience, either. Best of luck to you. Leea
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy + Thin and Flat-Chested

Posts.Content: Leeby, In my opinion, the report is positive: -They found no masses, solid or cystic. Yes, I believe a solid mass might suggest cancer. -Fibroglandular densities suggests fibrous tissue NOT cancer. And the findings show no change since 2005. -Focal asymetric density. - I would want to know if this requires further testing. I would ask, is this new and what could it mean? Most likely benign? Best of luck. I was dxed with breast ca. in 06 and doing well. Leea
Posts.Title: no solid or cystic mass in region

Posts.Content: Msdebegain- I think the guidelines are 5 yrs of either tamox and aromatase inhibitor or combination. It sounds like you did the tamox and then switched to femara for a total of 3.5yrs of therapy. - that is a big plus that you already have 3.5yrs of anti-hormone meds, "under your belt." I would guess the onc. might want to put you back on the femara, even though you had a break from it. I have read they are doing studies to see if the AIs should be taken even longer than 5yrs, depending on a pt's situation. I took tamox for 1.5yrs and have been on femara, also for 1yr, now. Leea
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen AND Femara

Posts.Content: I am taking tamoxafin also and know it CAN cause elevated liver enzymes. So hopefully it may be something like that rather than recurrance. -Although recurrance can happen at any time, it is a very good sign that your mom has gone for 5 years with good reports. Hoping all will be well. Leea
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Survivor with Elevated Liver Enzymes

Posts.Content: GAP- I agree. The only way to know for sure is to have a biopsy. You are totally right to insist that this be checked out. Don't let any Dr. intimidate you-If you feel something is not right. Many pt's breast cancer's have been "missed" by mammogram, so it is not unheard of, at all. I am almost a 1yrs survivor (May 23rd) of stage 1 breast cancer. Mine was found by mammogram. Let us know how it goes. Best of luck to you. Leea
Posts.Title: Breast lump-normal mammogram?

Posts.Content: Sydney, Your recovery may be a little different, since you are doing the mast/DIEP together. When I did the bilateral mast initially, it took a week to get my range of motion and then maybe a couple of more wks for my arms to feel pretty much back to normal. They will give you exercises, like having you walk your fingers up the side of a wall to help with this, after you heal. But the 1st wk after surgery, they will advise to not raise your arms too much. For example, I had to have someone help me get thing's out of the cupboard, because it was too high to reach. When I did my reconstruction, 9mths later, I had no problems at all with range of motion. Best of luck for a good surgery and speedy recovery. Leea
Posts.Title: mastectomy/reconstruction 1 2

Posts.Content: TJ, Just checking in on you. You have certainly had a full plate with all the decisions to consider. And then to top it all off, the crane accident near your home. - When it rains it pours! I'm not sure if you are still thinking about reconstruction. I had bilateral like you and waited 9mths to reconstruct. They can do immediate but I was just too overwhelmed to decide then. If you want any more info about my reconstruct experience, just let me know. You have a great attitude and i'm glad your treatment plan is falling into place. Hope the next couple of weeks go well for you and keep us posted. Leea
Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy Results 1 2

Posts.Content: TJ, I know what you mean about worrying about it spreading. - The docs usually say a few extra weeks won't matter, but their not the ones dealing with the fear. I remember, I would not lay on my stomach, as I was afraid, by "squishing" the breast, I might cause it to spread. - I couldn't get to surgery soon enough. It is hard to tell your children. I waited about a week because they were just getting done with the school year (late May of 06). They were 15 and 9 at the time. - Both boys. I told them separately because of the age difference. My 9yr old is the "emotional one". He cried many times and asked if I was going to die. I told him, No. - that they had caught it early. He is doing better know, since it has been almost 2yrs. My 15 yr old has 2 good friend's whose moms both had breast cancer and are doing well. He said, "Mom lots of people get breast cancer but hardly anyone dies from it." So I think he kind of took it in stride. Good luck with telling your children. I hope you may still be able to visit your daughter, late April. Depending on your treatment, you might still be able to go. - I had bilateral mast, June 8th of 06 and was down in Florida for a family vacation by July 4th. Keep us posted. Leea
Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy Results 1 2

Posts.Content: TJ, So glad you get to see the surgeon Monday. Being on the "breast cancer journey" is a huge emotional roller coaster. I cried alot too ,for all kinds of different reasons, especially the 1st year. I was probably most emotional, last March after I was home from my bilateral breast reconstruction. I think I was partly just exhausted and releived it was over (A tissue flap reconstruction which took over 7hrs.) Like you, I also thought about all the wonderful health care professionals, family and friends who had helped me during the year to get to that point. Let us know when you are having surgery. - Hope all goes well tomorrow. Leea
Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy Results 1 2

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add my 2 cents. I had the stereotactic biopsy also. It wasn't too bad. As I remember, (2yrs ago), it took about 30 minutes. - The radiologist DID have to go in a 2nd time, as she did not get enough tissue the 1st time. Unfortuately mine was positive for breast cancer, but I have a family hx. It was caught very early though, and I should be fine. Hope all goes well. With the valium, you should be fairly relaxed. Leea
Posts.Title: scared, please help

Posts.Content: Klo- Yes, usually they do a mammogram 1st or in conjunction with an ultrasound. As, I understand it, the tests pick up slightly different information: The mammogram shows there is "something there," where as a ultrasound may suggest whether it is solid or fluid-filled, like a cyst. The only way to know for sure is to biopsy it. - Remember 80% of lumps are beneign, but I would definitely check it out, just to make sure. I had a diagnostic mammogram and mine took about a wk to get back. Let them know you want a call with the results and not just a letter in the mail. Best of luck. Leea
Posts.Title: mammogram after an ultrasound????

Posts.Content: I have been on Femara almost a yr and was on tamox for 1.5yrs. That is a hard question and you are so right about all the SEs of these aromatase inhibitors. - I have the joint aches and stiffness too. I did not get bone density testing (my choice) as I knew I did not want to take the Fosomax or any of the others, d/t SEs (the one that concerns me the most is "jaw necrosis" - Supposedly rare, but I have known several people on this that have had jaw/dental issues). Anyway, since you are at high risk for recurrance, I don't know if I would want to risk it. It is good your vit D is in normal range. These are the things I learned from visiting another br ca site re bone loss: -Are you able to exercise? Any weight bearing exercise including walking is good. I have read some get very good results with wt training 2-3 times/wk. -Also, some oncs are recommending higher doses of vit D: -Vit D 2000mg/day. -Calcium 1500mg/day. -Magnesium (very important for bones) 500mg/day. For better absorption, it is supposed to be taken at a different time than the calcium. You could ask your doc. if these amounts are Ok to take. Also, I have read some Oncs. are rxing Evista which preserves bone and protects against breast cancer at the same time. (Kind of like tamox but with less SEs). Anyway, if you can I would really step up the exercise and see if upping your vitamins/minerals is OK with your doc. Leea
Posts.Title: significant bone loss with femara

Posts.Content: TJ, So sorry to hear. It is surreal at 1st and the waiting is hard. This is probably the worst part, not knowing. Once you get a treatment plan, it will get a little easier. I WOULD take a family member or close friend if possible to your initial meeting with the oncologist and surgeon. - Two sets of ears listening to the Dr's are better than one, to make sure you don't miss any details. If you are dxed as a stage one (as I was, almost 2yrs ago), you might want to ask about the oncotype dx test. - Your own tissue samples are sent for analysis. - They look at 21 features of your tumor and then give you a score to determine your recurrance risk in 10yrs. It is just another important tool to determine your treatment plan. -It is mainly used to decide how much you would benefit from chemo. In my case, I had a low score of 10, showing only a 1% benefit with chemo. Therefore I did not do chemo but did do anti hormone treatment, as my tumor was positive for hormones. You may also want to ask about: -hormone status of your tumor (estrogen and/or progesterone positive or neg) -her2nu status. -grade of your tumor (grade 1,2 or 3- grade 3 being most agressive). I will be thinking of you and praying for a good outcome. Let us know how you are doing. Leea
Posts.Title: Core Needle Biopsy Results 1 2

Posts.Content: Kris, I would notify your oncologist, as I understand the aromatase inhibitors won't work if you are still having periods. Your onc will probably switch you to tamoxafin until they are sure you are menopausal. Also ask your Dr. for periodic tests of your hormone levels (estradiol). Some also test for FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone). Menopause is defined as no periods for 1 year, although I have heard of survivors whose periods come back after one year. That is why it is so important to test the hormones to ensure the person is truly menopausal before starting an AI. I am a 1.5yr survivor and just started Femara about 2 mths ago. Leea
Posts.Title: periods while on arimidex

Posts.Content: Mindy, Not to scare you, but I just received an email tonight from a friend and breast cancer survivor (I am a survivor also) re Paget's dx. It was from a women who has paget's that metastisized. - She said the symptoms to look for are redness, possible oozing, a persisitent itch and or burn at the area and crusting on the outer edge of the lesion. - She said her treatment WAS delayed, as they thought it was dermatitis and that her only symtoms was the crusty outer edge and it started as a sore or pimple. She said it is especially important to check it out if it is only on ONE breast, as paget's rarely occurs on both breasts. From her experience, she said it is dxed by getting a mammogram of both breasts and having the skin lesion biopsyed immediately. To make sure, I would insist on these tests and don't let them talk you out of it. - It is better to be safe and if you have a biopsy, you will know for sure. - It could be something totally harmless, but why take a chance?? This lady did not have many symptoms. - the sore was just annoying and they delayed checking re breast cancer. - Now she has mets, when it could have been discovered earlier. Again, a good chance your's is nothing but why risk it? Leea
Posts.Title: Re: Paget's Disease

Posts.Content: Nan, I have not experienced what you have but sending good wishes that all will be well. Just to make sure, if it were me, I would get the biopsy. It is easy for our minds to run away with bad thoughts, but it could be so many things other than cancer. The biopsy will give you peace of mind. Let us know how it goes. Leea
Posts.Title: Lump under clavicle

Posts.Content: Prayers and good thoughts for you and your wife. Please continue to update. I was dxed in May of 06. It is surreal at times but she WILL get through it. Hoping the chemo goes well for her. Leea
Posts.Title: Possible breast cancer 1 2

Posts.Content: Alot of times, oncologist's disagree on the best treatment as it is not always black and white. If your MIL is early stage with no lymph node involovement, she may be able to take the Oncotype dx test, which analyzes 21 genes of her particular tumor, to determine the chances of recurrance within 10 yrs on anti-hormone therapy only. I had the test done and my score came back a low #10, which suggested that I had a 93% chance of NO recurrance in 10 yrs with anti-hormone thereapy alone. In my situation, chemo would have given very little benefit. This test, as well as statistics from adjuvantoline (which the oncologist can obtain for you) helped me to make my decision. The oncotype dx test is very well known in the breast cancer community and is a good tool to help make decisions regarding chemo. It might be worth it to research these tests and ask the oncologist's, on behalf of your MIL, if these tests/stats would be helpful in her situation. You could also get a 3rd opinion. It is always good if you can go to a major cancer center if possible for opinions, as they are usually up on the latest. Best wishes to your MIL. Leea
Posts.Title: MRI with radiation question

Posts.Content: JM- I had a lump at the armpit many yrs ago. My doc said to watch it for 2 mths and follow-up with him, as in young women, it can just be hormonal changes. Sure enough, in 2 mths it was gone. Here's hoping this is just a beneign condition but definitely see your doc to be sure. Leea
Posts.Title: Lump under armpit....i'm scared...help!!

Posts.Content: Coco- I was dxed with early stage br cancer in May 2006 and am doing well. I had some microcalcifications in the other breast the yr, prior, but otherwise had clean mammograms. I was 48 at the time. We have a family hx, so it was always a little in the back of my mind. Anyway, I did not have any pain. I felt no lump. It was small and was caught early on mammo. No node invovement. - If it is cancer, they determine the node status during surgery (usually a sentinal node biopsy these days, which only looks at the 1st 1-2 nodes. - If those are clean, the rest should be clean as well). It took about a week for me to receive a letter saying I needed more mammos and an ultrasound. then I had a core needle biopsy. Hope this answers yoru questions. Try not to worry too much. alot of women receive call - back letters, and even go through biopsys, with totally beneign results. Leea
Posts.Title: Question for those who have had or have Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I know your scared. - Please keep posting and let us know how it goes. Hugs and best wishes to you. Leea
Posts.Title: Question for those who have had or have Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: The report sounds like good news, but if you are concerned and would like them to recheck sooner, maybe 3 mths, I would do that. Better safe than sorry. Leea
Posts.Title: Bi-rads 3

Posts.Content: Sometimes small lumps form d/t hormonal changes and then go away, once you have your peroid. I had a lump under my arm many yrs ago. The Dr. said wait 2 mths and see if it is still a problem. - In that time it went away. While it is certainly possible to get breast cancer in your 30s, it is more likely it would be something else, at such a young age. You are definetely smart to check it out though. Best of luck. Leea
Posts.Title: what else can cause "lumps"?

Posts.Content: Awesome!! Go celebrate! Leah
Posts.Title: Question for those who have had or have Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Michelle- I really think it is probably peri or menopause, because I am going through the same thing re weight gain and a "spare tire" that I never had before. Have they tested your hormones? Are you having any other symptoms like hot flashes? I have read that low hormones, such as in menopause, caused by chemo, tamox, or ovarian shut down like lupron/zolodex can make it much harder to lose wt or cause wt gain. I was 48, like you, when dxed 2.5yrs ago. Premenopausal. I did not have chemo but did have zolodex shot/tamox. Then I had ovary removal Feb. 08, which I regret. I have always been lean and fit/always exercised and eat pretty healthy. Since the ovary removal, especiallly, I have put on around 8ibs, it seems like, "out of nowhere." (alot on a small frame). Also the flabby middle. My thyroid is fine. I exercise and wt train 6 days/wk, but realize without any hormones to help metabolism etc., I will need to really watch my diet to keep the wt gain at bay or hopefully loose wt. Anyway, I think it is totally normal that it would be harder to lose with changes to hormones. Sound's like you are making steady progress. - It just might take a little longer. Good luck. Leea
Posts.Title: Chemo, Menapause, Taximofen

Posts.Content: The oncotype dx test IS only for invasive cancer. Stage 0 is not invasive, meaning to my knowledge, stage 0 does not break through the cell wall. Thus, stage 0 does not invade surrounding tissue and has 0% chance to spread. So for your particular diagnosis of stage 0 that you have now, there is NO risk of recurrance. - However, I believe anyone who has had DCIS is at some higher risk of invasive cancer in the future. I think whether to take tamox is a toss-up. It most likely would provide some benefit in lowering your risk of more DCIS or an invasive cancer, but the question is, "Would the benefit outweigh the side effects and risks and by how much, percentage wise?" ( some potentially serious like blood clots, stroke and in rare cases uterine cancer.) As one of the oncologist's said, if I were pre-menopausal I might consider it more seriously, as in premenopause there is so much more estrogen to fuel a potential breast cancer. Hope this helps. Leea
Posts.Title: MRI with radiation question

Posts.Content: From what I know, DCIS is a precancer that has not yet broken through the breast duct wall and therefore cannot travel to the lymph nodes or other areas of the body. If there is a GOOD cancer to get, it would be DCIS. Another good thing about your mom's situation, is that as an older, postmenopausal women, the cancer is probably a slow grower. Do you know what grade she had? - Grade 1 and 2 are usually not terrribly agressive but grade 3 IS aggressive. - I would expect she is a grade 1 or 2. One thing I would question is the need for chemo? Is she getting a 2nd opinion? From what I know, visiting another breast ca site, DCIS usually does not require chemo, as the tumor is not invasive. Good luck to you and your mom, with her treatment plan. Glad she is a long term survivor from an earlier breast ca. My mom is 29 yrs out from her dx and is now 84yrs old. I am a 2 year survivor with a very good prognosis and hope to live a long life, like my mom. Leea
Posts.Title: How serious is DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ)?

Posts.Content: Hi- I am a survivor, 48 at dx and now 50. I did not have her2+ but was er+ and can tell you what I know, mostly from visiting another board, where there are all types of Br. cancer dxs. Since you are BRCA+, as you said, they will want to give you chemo and then I believe because you are her2+, they will give you hercepton, at some point. With er+ breast cancer they are trying to avoid any stimulation of possible breast cancer cells in the blood, so I'm not sure they would encourage a pregnancy, at least not for a few years. I have read about ooph/hyst in breast cancer pts. For the er+ part of your cancer, some studies show an ooph/hyst benefits younger women much more than older women, in terms of recurrance. Since you are BRCA+ they may be recommending an ooph, as BRCA1 and BRCA2 have a higher chance of developing ovarian cancer. Having an ooph is a very big and personal decision, as you loose all the benefits of your hormones including being able to have a child (Although I've heard of some women freezing their eggs, before they have an ooph). Anyway, you are asking very thoughtful, important questions. Your oncologist needs to explain fully the pros/cons of any treatment and a 2nd opinion may be helpful, as well. Best of luck, Leea
Posts.Title: breast cancer ER+, HER2+, BRCA1+

Posts.Content: Hi Marcine The Brca 1 and 2 ARE genes that indicate a person is at higher risk for breast and/or ovarian cancer. I tested negative for the brca genes but do have a family hx with my mom, maternal grandma and aunt. I developed early stage br cancer in May 2006 and am doing well. The counselor is right. Her2 is a protein that causes breast cancer cells to replicate faster. For this, hercepton is usually given and works well. It sounds like your mom was tested for her2 but most likely did NOT have the brca test. The brca test is a blood test and the her2 test is a test on the tumor, to see what features it has. The brca test is very expensive. Insurance usually pays for at least part of it. The reason I believe they would like to have your mom tested, is that if she is negative, it will indicate you donot have the gene either. - In other words, then you don't have to test too. Hope this helps. Leea
